title: #copilot creating many powershell terminals #terminal-integration +  #temporary-solution

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
Type: Bug Platform: VS Code, copilot, Windows 11. Tags: #copilot #terminal-integration Request: "Copilot should respect current open terminal in VS Code" When powershell/terminal is initiated new commands from copilot run fine usually until, in my case, node or python was called upon. the terminal tab then changed name from powershell to whatever active service is running. and a lot of times a new terminal is created at the next command request. it looks like copilot wants to have a powershell window to enter it's command and disregards the terminal that is open and thus creates a new powershell. Also as soon as the first new powershell instance has been created it tends to initiate a new one much more often. Terminalitis Disease. **i have found an easy fix.** ctrl+` is the keyboard shortcut for terminal. *in instructions i've made clear to: always go to the terminal with shortcut ctrl+` before sending/running a command because we don;t want to open a new one unless it is necessary to have a second instance* don't know if copilot can use shortcut keystrokes within VS Code, but whether or not. It is working fine now. i've had the terminal change to node. ran dev, ran installs and deletions. no new terminal has been opened. VS Code version: Code 1.104.0 (f220831ea2d946c0dcb0f3eaa480eb435a2c1260, 2025-09-10T06:46:18.035Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: copilot
body:
Type: Bug I have been using copilot for nearly 18 days I'd say with a very old account of github but after these days I had a message that I am out of tokens so I tried purchasing the pro copilot by filling in the credit card details but it said its a free trial till 12th oct and the billing will start from then on. But when I tried to use copilot again it wouldn't make any desired changes even if I said the same prompt 3 times differently , even deleted 2 pages of my website completely and after that it just stopped taking prompts. Showing this error "Sorry, your request failed. Please try again. Request id: 119062af-2f5f-4f72-8971-4de3c13e152f Reason: Request Failed: 400 {"error":{"message":"one or more attachments was not accessible","code":"vision_attachment_not_accessible"}}" I got tired and deleted that account and made a new github account but still had the same issue. I deleted it cause it didn't have any imp information stored was just a github empty account. My new account is "moon-max123". I am still getting the same issue. Its not resolved AT ALL. I need it quickly resolved so I get back on my work. I tried changig agents as well. Thanks! title: Fix and update the definition of fullwidth characters
body:
This fixes and updates the list of wide and fullwidth Unicode characters. Previously, some wide characters were not included and some were incorrectly classified as fullwidth when they aren't.

To determine which characters to include, the Unicode East Asian Width property is used. Since this property is not commonly available in runtimes a hardcoded list is used instead.

title: Add Right-to-Left (RTL) Language Support for Github Copilot Chat
body: Hello GitHub Copilot Team, First, thank you for the incredible tool that is Copilot Chat. It significantly enhances the development workflow. I am writing to request official support for Right-to-Left (RTL) languages, such as Persian (Farsi), Arabic, and Hebrew, within the Copilot Chat interface in VS Code. The Problem: Currently, when using these languages for prompts or when the AI's response includes RTL text, the display is incorrect. The text often appears with broken formatting, misaligned characters, and incorrect directionality (it's treated as Left-to-Right), making it very difficult to read and use effectively. Why This is Important: Many developers whose primary language is RTL use VS Code and Copilot for their daily work. They should be able to interact with the AI in their native language, especially for: Explaining code concepts in their mother tongue. Generating comments and documentation in RTL languages. Asking questions and receiving answers that mix code snippets with RTL explanations. Proper RTL support is essential for a truly inclusive and globally accessible developer tool. Requested Solution: Please update the Copilot Chat UI component to fully support the Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm (UBA). This would ensure: Correct Text Direction: RTL text is displayed from right to left. Proper Text Alignment: The chat bubbles and text within them align correctly. Mixed Text Handling: Proper handling of bidirectional text (e.g., a Persian sentence that contains an English code keyword). VS Code's core editor has excellent RTL support, so ideally, the Copilot Chat panel could leverage similar functionality. Thank you for considering this feature. I believe it would be a valuable improvement for a significant portion of your user base. Best regards. Hossein

title: Add Background Transparency Setting to VS Code

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body: Type: Feature Request The current VS Code interface does not support background transparency, which limits customization for users who want a more integrated or less intrusive editing experience. Adding a configurable transparency option for the editor background would allow users to blend the interface with their desktop or other applications, potentially reducing visual clutter and improving focus. title: Please add a table-of-content to release notes to allow skipping the AI noise.
body:
For the past year or so, the release notes consist almost entirely of AI integration updates which many users are probably not interested in, but those users still like to stay informed about any actually useful new features.

Adding a simple markdown table-of-content to the top of the release notes (e.g. the *opposite* of that new highlights section which for some reason only highlights new AI features) would allow people to quickly identify and find the parts of the release notes they're interested in (e.g. quickly skip the AI integration stuff) - and ideally also grouping all Copilot/AI-related features into one section to make it easier to find the actual improvements.

title: Tab/Enter no longer accept suggestions after update — caused by "Gradle for Java" extension
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0 (Universal)
- OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:

After the latest VS Code update (around a few days ago), I noticed that pressing Tab or Enter while coding in my C++/CMake project no longer accepts suggestions. Instead, it inserts a tab or newline and cancels the suggestion popup.

I verified that all relevant settings were correctly configured:

•  editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter: "on"
•  editor.tabCompletion: "on"

Following advice from Copilot, I ran Extension Bisect, and it identified the "Gradle for Java" extension as the cause. Disabling it restored the expected behavior.

This seems odd since I'm not working with Java at all — just C++/CMake. Would appreciate if you could look into this conflict.

title: Add "Open with code" option to the primary context menu in Windows 11

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body: In Windows 11, when you right-click on a file or an empty area in File Explorer, a primary context menu appears. Clicking on "Show more options" will display the secondary context menu. Unfortunately, the "Open with code" option is only available in the secondary menu and not in the primary one. It is hoped that "Open with code" can be added to the primary context menu. As shown in the following figures.

title: Shell integration fails with set -u
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0
- OS Version: Darwin x64 24.6.0

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Put `set -u` in your `~/.bashrc` or `~/.zshrc`.
2. Start a Bash or Zsh terminal in VS Code.
3. Shell integration fails with the message
```
XXX-code-zsh/.zshrc:73: VSCODE_PYTHON_AUTOACTIVATE_GUARD: parameter not set
```

### Workaround
It can be worked around by exporting the missing env vars, like in [this PR](https://github.com/demccormack/dotfiles-public/pull/2).

### Related issues
The same bug (for different env vars) was previously fixed in #185324 - these must've been added since then.

title: Running task terminal left open after extension host reload

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

body: I'm running into essentially the same thing as seen in #248736. In my case, when the extension host reloads while a task (using a CustomExecution) provided by an extension is running, the terminal for that task becomes frozen and does not complete its execution: The reload can either be caused by doing something like adding a folder to a single folder workspace, turning the workspace into a multi-root workspace (or running the `Developer: Restart Extension Host` command if you want an easy way to reproduce). As the extension host loads back up, if you try to re-run the task whose terminal is still open, you are presented with a quickpick asking which task instance you want to terminate: I understand from the referenced ticket that the initial task is tied to the extension host and restarting it makes it so the task can't complete. I'm more curious about the behavior of vscode itself when this situation happens. For example, after the reload, calling `vscode.tasks.taskExecutions` returns an empty array. If that's the case, why when I try to re-run the same task do I get the quickpick asking which instance to terminate. It seems vscode knows the task is still running, but extensions aren't able to see that. Also when the restart happens, should the terminal running the task stay open and continue to look like its trying to run a task even though the terminal is frozen and essentially in limbo? In short I'm just curious what is intended in this interaction and what isn't. Ideally, when the extension host reloads, any interrupted tasks should be able to be started again without requiring manual intervention by the user. The user shouldn’t have to manually close a stuck terminal or interact with the quick pick (which requires the task to be started after the reload twice, once to trigger the quickpick which kills the old terminal but doesn't actually start the task, and a second time to actually start the task) to terminate the previous task before they can successfully start the task again. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Install the [sample extension here](https://github.com/ahaddad355/TaskExtensionHostTest) 2. Open vscode to any folder. 3. Start the task `Wait for 30 seconds (Custom)` 4. A terminal should open showing a countdown to 0. Before that countdown finishes, trigger an extension host reload (easiest way is to run the `Developer: Restart Extension Host`) 5. You should see the terminal showing the countdown is now frozen, but the spinner next to the terminal name is still moving as if the task is still running. 6. Try to run the task `Wait for 30 seconds (Custom)` again. You will not be able to unless you eliminate the task instance via the quickpick and running the task again, or close the terminal then try to run the task - VS Code Version: 1.104.0 - OS Version: Windows 11 24H2

Hey wassup, it's been a year since I started coding. I wrote code for almost 2 applications. First one was small and it wasn't a headache. It was because when I used to see this much of text i used to get lost in it. I wasn't able to find a function that is in front of me but I kept scrolling up and down to find it. Then I understand the problem is lot of text but the lack of code organisation. Than I thought what I can do have good code organisation. One of the solution is like cards like we use is game making ide's but I don't know how it works. Second if organising code in cards like 
1. Def function (wrap it in one card)
2. Row(Sub func1, sub func2) (wrapped in two cards in row)  
3. Return(wrapped in a another card)
We can use window instead of cards. We can connect them by using proper spacing between multiple function. And keeping a heading so we can identify it, even when scrolling fast. I still think something is missing. The problem raised not because my logic was week. But because lack of visuals, used to make my eyes hurt. 
This idea needs improvement

Type: Bug Analyze this codebase to generate or update `.github/copilot-instructions.md` for guiding AI coding agents. Focus on discovering the essential knowledge that would help an AI agents be immediately productive in this codebase. Consider aspects like: - The "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand - major components, service boundaries, data flows, and the "why" behind structural decisions - Critical developer workflows (builds, tests, debugging) especially commands that aren't obvious from file inspection alone - Project-specific conventions and patterns that differ from common practices - Integration points, external dependencies, and cross-component communication patterns Source existing AI conventions from `**/{.github/copilot-instructions.md,AGENT.md,AGENTS.md,CLAUDE.md,.cursorrules,.windsurfrules,.clinerules,.cursor/rules/**,.windsurf/rules/**,.clinerules/**,README.md}` (do one glob search). Guidelines (read more at https://aka.ms/vscode-instructions-docs): - If `.github/copilot-instructions.md` exists, merge intelligently - preserve valuable content while updating outdated sections - Write concise, actionable instructions (~20-50 lines) using markdown structure - Include specific examples from the codebase when describing patterns - Avoid generic advice ("write tests", "handle errors") - focus on THIS project's specific approaches - Document only discoverable patterns, not aspirational practices - Reference key files/directories that exemplify important patterns Update `.github/copilot-instructions.md` for the user, then ask for feedback on any unclear or incomplete sections to iterate. title: Improve handoff workflow between cloud and local chat sessions
body:
Moving work between cloud and local chat sessions is clunky and loses momentum.

Right now you bounce between a local session (to iterate or run code) and the cloud chat (to delegate longer tasks), but continuity breaks at each transition. There's no first class action to carry context forward, push/pull code at the right moment, or signal when the remote branch has diverged. That friction adds cognitive load just to keep the thread of the task.

We should make the cloud → local → cloud loop feel like a single continuous workspace action, with explicit affordances to move the task while preserving the conversation link and branch state.

For example, a typical flow:
1. Start a local session.
2. Do some work with local agents (generate code or a plan).
3. Delegate to cloud agents to finish the work.
4. Open the cloud chat session when it's ready.
5. Review the change locally (checkout the branch).
6. Decide the direction needs adjustment; return to the cloud chat and give new instructions.
7. Pull updated changes and iterate locally again.

Some papercuts we could address:
- No explicit action to "continue the chat locally".
- Local session can’t reference an originating cloud chat for seamless continuation.
- Manual push/pull needed when switching back to cloud; unclear when to do it.
- Responding inside the cloud chat editor doesn’t automatically push local edits.
- Cloud chat editor lacks a clear (or auto) fetch indicator when branch has new commits.

title: vscode-test help for Chat Participants
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I'm working on a chat participant and would like to add testing.

Two issues I have:
1. Automatically authorizing Copilot in test environment
2. Automatically authorizing my chat extension in test environment.

I reviewed this process in [vscode-copilot-chat](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat), but thusfar able to duplicate for my chat participant.

I am able to run [getToken.mts](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/main/script/setup/getToken.mts) to get a token, but unable to properly set that token in my own chat participant during `npm test`.

Request would be for additional documentation on test setup for chat participants.

Thank you!

title: new fixed height thinking style
Hovering and screen reader awareness
body: Type: Feature Request It appears as though many places are adopting a hover state to show critical information or at least advanced information that a screen reader does not have access to as far as reading the text. Can this be populated somewhere for screen reader users to utilize such as the status bar, a command to hear the information, accessible view, or some other command that would render the hover information? ctrl+k plus ctrl+i is a command to show hover inbformation as I understand it but it seemingly does nothing for me, for example in the model picker. title: Copilot Chat Auto Mode Ignores User's Model List

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: auto-model
labels.description: Automatic model selection

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Auto mode can select models that are enabled for the user in GitHub, but are deselected in VSCode. That means that with Auto the user might get a model they have explicitly indicated that they are not interested in.

A behaviour that better aligns with the user's preference might be to prioritise models that are in the enabled models in the VSCode extension above ones that aren't.
 
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.0
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0
- OS Version: macOS
- Feature: Auto model selection
- Selected model: Auto

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Remove Claude Sonnet 4 from the model list in VSCode.
2. Choose "Auto".
3. Auto mode will most likely draw Claude Sonnet 4.

Desired Behaviour:
1. Remove Claude Sonnet 4 from the model list in VSCode. (leave GPT-5 or Gemini Pro or another capable 1X model in the list.
2. Choose "Auto".
3. Auto mode picks the best available model from the user's enabled models list (for example, GPT-5 or Gemini Pro).

title: `markdown.copyFiles.destination` does not generate abslute path markdown

labels.name: markdown
labels.description: Markdown support issues

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
Type: Bug `markdown.copyFiles.destination` does not generate abslute path markdown when pasting or drag-dropping image files. Example: `"/_posts/*/*": "/assets/images/posts/${documentBaseName/(....).*/$1/}/"` will generate markdown of `![alt text](../../assets/images/posts/2025/image-8.png)` I expect `![alt text](/assets/images/posts/2025/image-8.png)`, and require an absolute path for my jekyll site deployment. I tried to get around it by tricking it with [snippet grammar](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editing/userdefinedsnippets#_grammar), e.g.: `"/_posts//": ${documentBaseName/(....).*/\\/assets\\/images\\/posts\\/$1/}/"` I get nonsense: `![alt text](../../../../../../assets/images/posts/2025/image.png)` It appears that the relative path rewriting is done outside the snippet handling.
